title: Toggle ith Bit

articles.title: Toggle bits in a given range

patternTriggers: Toggle (flip) a bit? Use XOR with 1 at that position: n ^ (1 << i)

approaches.name: Check Then Set/Clear - Brute Force
approaches.intuition: First check if bit is set. If set, clear it. If clear, set it.
approaches.approach: Use conditional logic to determine operation.
steps: Check if ith bit is set: (n & (1 << i)) != 0

approaches.name: Using Subtraction
approaches.intuition: Toggle by adding or subtracting power of 2 based on current state.
approaches.approach: Add (1 << i) if bit is 0, subtract if bit is 1.

approaches.name: XOR Operation - Optimal
approaches.intuition: XOR with 1 flips a bit. 0 XOR 1 = 1, 1 XOR 1 = 0. Perfect for toggling!
approaches.approach: Use XOR with a mask that has 1 at position i.

commonMistakes: Using OR instead of XOR (only sets, doesn't toggle)
Using AND instead of XOR (only clears, doesn't toggle)
Forgetting to shift: n ^ 1 only toggles LSB
Off-by-one error in bit position (0-indexed vs 1-indexed)
Not handling edge cases like i >= 32
hints: XOR is your friend for toggling
Create mask with 1 at position i: (1 << i)
